awd_titl_txt: Cognitive, Physiological, and Mental Health Implications of Cultural Variation in Emotion Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Negative emotions happen every day and those thoughts and feelings can undermine a person's success and health. Research shows that the harmful effects of negative emotions are greater among Americans compared to East Asians. This project focuses on understanding how negative emotions assert their negative influence. It considers whether the way a person views and interprets negative emotions influences the effects of those emotions. One theory is that unfavorable beliefs about negative emotions make those negative emotions more harmful. The primary hypothesis is that negative emotions per se are not negative. How people respond to those negative emotions, however, produces the negative outcomes. Research suggests that Americans, compared to East Asians, view negative emotions as more harmful. Such differences in how people think about negative emotions produce the negative outcomes. This project lays the foundation for the design of interventions that promote more effective ways to respond to negative emotions. The research will help teachers improve the learning and success of their students and help counselors who work with patients who have mood and anxiety disorders.  

This project examines the cognitive, physiological, mental health, and performance outcomes of cultural differences in beliefs about negative emotions. Multiple behavioral experiments examine how people respond to stressful events. Measures of cognitive, behavioral, and hormonal responses are used to compare American with East Asian samples. Stress responses to emotional experiences and arousal are measured via cortisol. Participants respond to different demanding tasks (such as giving a speech or doing difficult math problems) to test for performance and physiological reaction differences to the stressors. Interpretations of one's negative emotions are measured to test for subsequent outcome differences in stress and performance. This project helps to develop more general principles about the causes and effects of negative emotions. In addition to advancing the fields of psychology and affective neuroscience, this research offers many practical and applied implications for improving student success and developing interventions for patients with mood and anxiety disorders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many studies conducted in Western countries indicate that negative emotions and negative thoughts have adverse behavioral and physiological consequences, including lower performance on cognitive tasks and maladaptive neuroendocrine responses to demanding and stressful life events. However, recent cross-cultural research has found weaker evidence for similar adverse effects of negative emotions in East Asian countries, where relatively more favorable beliefs about negative emotions and thoughts exist when compared to Western countries. In this project, we investigated whether holding unfavorable beliefs about negative emotions and thoughts makes those emotions and thoughts more harmful across Western and Eastern cultural contexts. To address this question, we assessed mental health, physiological, and behavioral outcomes. 

We first examined whether the processing of negative information before and after a stressful event is associated with worse mental health outcomes, and whether unfavorable views of negative thoughts exacerbated these associations. In an international study across six nations (U.K., U.S., Australia, China, South Korea, and Japan), we showed that Westerners were less likely than East Asians to hold positive beliefs about worrying and that, among respondents who held less positive beliefs about worrying, that processing negative information before a demanding I.Q. test was more strongly associated with symptoms indicative of poorer mental health. In another series of studies comparing Americans from European family backgrounds and East Asians living in the U.S., we showed that European Americans were more likely than East Asians to hold negative beliefs about rumination and that, among those who held a negative belief about rumination, rumination was more strongly associated with depressive symptoms. Furthermore, among Asians, the longer they lived in the U.S., the stronger their beliefs about rumination had shifted, suggesting there was effect of acculturation on negative beliefs about rumination. These findings suggest that the processing of negative information before and after a stressful/negative event can be more impactful on mental health if one holds negative beliefs about negative thoughts, and that these perspectives can be shaped by cultural contexts. 

To examine physiological and behavioral outcomes, hormonal and behavioral responses to a stressful task were investigated in European American and East Asian students living in the U.S. to determine whether holding more favorable beliefs about negative emotions would attenuate the students' reactions. Using standardized cognitive and emotional tasks, we determined that among European American students (but not among East Asians), the respondents who held positive views about negative emotions released lower levels of cortisol, a stress-related hormone, into their saliva and also recovered more quickly. At the same time, across both cultures, the students who held more positive views about negative emotion had better performances on the task requiring them to deliver a speech. In addition, we conducted a naturalistic evaluation of the daily hormonal rhythms of European American and East Asian students living in the U.S. across three days during the school semester when all students were contending with the recent COVID-19 pandemic. Stresses due to completing coursework and stress related to COVID-19 were associated with divergent cortisol levels, and having positive beliefs about negative emotions moderated the association between course-related stress (but not COVID-19-related concerns) and cortisol levels.  These findings provided partial support for the hypothesized role of beliefs about negative emotions in helping to regulate and moderate physiological and behavioral responses to stressful life events. The results also highlight the need for further research on beliefs about the value and usefulness of negative emotions, as well as other factors that can moderate this influence.

Finally, we tested whether beliefs about negative emotions can be changed through experience and practice. In research conducted both in the U.S. and Japan, students were randomly assigned to write about the positive aspects of experiencing negative emotions or as a control, were asked to write essays about neutral topics for five days. We found that the experimental manipulation was successful in enhancing the participants' beliefs about the potential value and benefits of negative emotions, at least in the short term. Most importantly, those students who underwent the largest change and increase in viewing negative emotions to be more positive, experienced the largest benefit. Among them, the amount of negative emotion experienced during the assessment week was less strongly linked to symptoms associated with poor mental health both a day after the assessment week and also one month later. These findings help to inform about novel therapeutic interventions that could be applied with people from different cultural backgrounds.  Overall, the research highlights the importance of including participants from diverse backgrounds in order to be able to generalize research conclusions to all populations.
